page.title: 05KERSEY
page.content: Kersey is built in a v-shaped valley. It is unusual because it is built across the valley and not along it.This means that the main village street has very steep sides with the buildings on the slope. In the centre of Kersey is a ford were the River Brett runs through the village. Many of the buildings have oak timber frames these are filled with clay,straw and hazel twigs (wattle and daub)which are protected by plastering. On some of the plaster you can see patterns,this is called pargetting.Most of the houses are thatched which was the earliest material used.The pantiles came next,followed by the slate.Nearly all the buildings date from between the fifteenth and seventeenth centuries.
